bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Henry C. Culpepper was born in west of Tarboro, N.C., at Hilma, the home of his parents, Laura Chivers and John L. Culpepper, Jr., on 7 January 1861. He was an athlete, attorney, railroad man, and entrepreneur. He attended school locally and as a youth was noted for his collection of several hundred varieties of birds’ eggs. When he was sixteen, he entered the University of the South at Sewanee, Tenn. and from there went to the University of North Carolina. At Chapel Hill he was a member of Sigma Nu Fraternity and the German Club, but his chief fame lay in his abilities in tennis, trap shooting, and golf. He helped represent the university in tennis and shooting and is credited with having introduced golf at Chapel Hill. He received his law degree in 1895 and returned home to join his father’s firm, Culpepper and Partners.

Within a few years Henry C. Culpepper had converted the western portion of his father’s homestead into a combined pasture-golf course and had built a railroad. The golf course, now Hilma Country Club, was one of the first in the state and has been played on continuously since 29 April 1899. When he was only twenty-two, he was elected president of the East Carolina Railway, which eventually ran from Tarboro to Hookerton, in Greene County, and literally created the towns of Pinetops, Macclesfield, and Fountain. As an attorney, he became local counsel for the Southern Railway. He let none of these activities interfere with sports, managing over the next twenty years to gather a large number of trophies in shooting, golf, and tennis and to achieve a modest national reputation in all three. Along with his railroad operation, Henry C. Culpepper became active in banking; by 1913 he had been made president of the First National Bank in Tarboro and the banks of Conetoe, Pinetops, Macclesfield, Fountain, and Hookerton. He was also president of ten other companies. In addition, he had acquired substantial farmlands, which he operated successfully; but unlike his father and grandfather, he had no inborn love of the soil. Briefly he ventured into publishing, acquiring a short-lived control of the Tarboro Southerner. He had a keen mind, a driving energy, and diverse interests.

On 12 January 1912, Henry C. Culpepper married Mary Meade Bernard of Petersburg, Va., daughter of Lucia Beverly Morrison and Judge David Meade Bernard II. They had a son, Henry C., Jr. (“Chivey”), and a daughter, Lucia Beverly. In 1924 they completed a Georgian-colonial home in Tarboro called Merrienmeade, for which the architect, Dwight James Baum of New York, received national recognition. Henry C. Culpepper died on 13 October 1951 at Merrienmeade. Mary Meade died at Merrienmeade as well and they were both buried in the yard of Calvary Episcopal Church in Tarboro. A portrait of each is in the possession of their children.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of the Collection
scopecontent.p: This collection documents the activities of Henry C. Culpepper, who was an athlete, attorney, railroad man, and entrepreneur. It includes correspondence, financial and legal materials including contracts, court documents, and related correspondence, journals, photographs and eggs specimens.

The correspondence series documents family letters to Henry C. Culpepper’s forebears, especially his grandfather, John Luther Culpepper, and his father John Luther Culpepper, Jr. There are also about 20 letters from John Luther Culpepper to his wife, Rebecca Louisa Dicken Culpepper, while he was serving with Company A of the 1st North Carolina Infantry Regiment during the Civil War. These letters discuss military life and the general progress of the war and advice on how to run the family businesses in Henry’s absence. Correspondence starts to relate his education at the University of North Carolina in the mid-1980s. Letters from Chapel Hill chiefly discuss his successful promotion of golf at the University and his other sporting activities. There is little information about his academic pursuits. In the late 1890s, letters relate chiefly to his railroad, law, and sporting activities. Beginning in 1925 and continuing until 1951, there is considerable correspondence documenting the bitter and sometimes violent dispute among Henry C. Culpepper, his cousin, actress and writer Ann Preston Culpepper. After Henry C. Culpepper’s death in 1951, there are scattered family letters including a few relating to Henry C. Culpepper, Jr.’s career decision. After 1965, there are many letters relating to Henry C. Culpepper, Jr.’s daughter Penelope Culpepper Hayes’s marriage and permanent move to England and fledgling writing career.

The financial and legal materials series relating to the construction and on-going maintenance of the Hilma Country Club on land developed as a golf course by Henry C. Culpepper in the late 1890s and first half of the twentieth century. contains letters to contractors and others, construction plans and drawings, maintenance contracts, event documentation. Materials relating to Henry C. Culpepper’s youthful collecting of several hundred varieties of birds’ eggs from 1886 to 1892 are kept in this collection. There are also journals Culpepper kept that document how and where he got his birds’ eggs. There are several hundred photographs of Culpepper and his eggs, Culpepper in locations where he found eggs, and close-ups of eggs and even 66 physical eggs that survive from the collection.
Finally, the Henry C. Culpepper papers give a sense of his life, activities including egg collecting and sports, businesses, and relationships between his family members.

scopecontent.head: Scope and content:
scopecontent.p: Early letters are chiefly rountine family letters to Henry C. Culpepper's forebears, especially to his grandfather John Luther Culpepper, and his father John Luther Culpepper, Jr. There are almost 20 letters from John Luther Culpepper to his wife, Rebecca Louisa Dicken Culpepper, while he was serving with Company A of Ist North Carolian Infanty Regiment during the Civil War. These letters discuss military life and hte general progress of the war; they also offer advice on how to run the family businesses in his absence.

Henry C. Culpepper correspondence starts with his studying at the University of North Carolina in the mid-1890s. Leters from Chapel Hill chiefly discuss Culpepper's successful promotion of golf at the University and his other sporting activities. Letters begins in the late 1890s relate chiefly to his railroad, law, and sporting activities.

There is considerable correspondence documenting the bitter and sometimes violent dispute among Henry C. Culpepper, his cousin, actress and writer Ann Preston Culpepper, and her co-writer and friend, playwright George Abbott, about Ann's devotion to Christian Science. These letters show Henry voicing strong opposition to her views, Ann defending her right to believe as she wished, and George occasionally suggesting in no uncertain terms what Henry could do with his opposition.

After Culpepper's death in 1951, there are scattered family letters including a few relating to Henry C. Culpepper, Jr.'s (Chivey) decision to end his 30-year career as an aviator with the United States Navy due to bad health and his desire to return to the family in Tarboro. After 1965, there are many letters relating to Chivey's daughter Penelope Culpepper Hayes's marriage and permanent move to England and to her fledgling writing career both as a travel writer and as a children's author under the Rob Ready pen name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and content:
scopecontent.p: This series contains financial and legal materials which are organized into two groups.

There are about 70 items dated from 1896 to 1950, and a few undated materials in the subseries I, relating to the construction and on-going maintenance of the Hilma Country Club on land developed as a golf course by Henry C. Culpepper in the late 1890s and first half of the twentieth century. Subseries I contains letters to contractors and others, construction plans and drawings, maintenance contracts, event documentation, and other items. Materials in subseries I are arranged chronologically.

Subseries II contains about 130 financial and legal items, chiefly contracts, court documents, and related correspondence, 1900-1951, documenting Culpepper's work with railroads, chief among them the Southern Railway; banks; and other business ventures. There are also materials documenting his agricultural pursuits. There is little to no documentation of his early work in the law firm, Culpepper and Partners. The materials in the Subseries II are arranged topically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and content:
scopecontent.p: Materials in this series relating to Henry C. Culpepper's youthful collecting of several hundred varieties of birds' eggs. There are about 20 correspondence between Culpepper and noted North Carolina ornithologist T. Gilbert Pearson. There are also journals Culpepper kept that document how and where he got his eggs; several hundred photographs of Culpepper and his eggs, Culpepper in locations where he found eggs, and close-ups of eggs; and physical eggs that survive from the collection (66 specimens). The materials are arranged by type. This series is CLOSED to research until the donor's book on Culpepper's egg collecting is published or 2035, whichever comes first.
